item.title: Pony AI Is Said to Confidentially File for Hong Kong Listing
item.description: Autonomous-driving company Pony AI Inc. has confidentially filed for a Hong Kong listing to help raise capital to grow its business, according to people familiar with the situation.
item.dc:creator: Dong Cao, Linda Lew

media:content.media:description: A Pony.ai Inc. autonomous-driving vehicle.

item.title: Tencent Grows Fastest Since 2021 in Solid Start to Rocky Year
item.description: Tencent Holdings Ltd.’s revenue grew at its fastest pace in more than three years, affirming investors’ expectations that China’s gaming and social media leader will weather a potential global downturn in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Zheping Huang

media:content.media:description: Signage at Tencent Holdings Ltd. offices in Shanghai.

item.title: Apple Partner Hon Hai Tempers Full-Year Sales Outlook
item.description: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., the main manufacturer of iPhones and Nvidia Corp.-powered AI servers, cut its guidance for full-year revenue growth to reflect potential fallout from the US trade war.
item.dc:creator: Jane Lanhee Lee

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Foxconn Technology Group's campus in Longhua district in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Sony Sees $700 Million Tariff Hit on Underwhelming Outlook
item.description: Sony Group Corp. offered an underwhelming forecast for the year ahead, with the burden of US tariffs wiping out expectations for an increase in operating profit.
item.dc:creator: Yuki Furukawa, Takashi Mochizuki

media:content.media:description: The Sony PlayStation 5 Pro controller. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Ackman Quits Universal Music Board to Focus on Recent Investments
item.description: Billionaire Bill Ackman resigned from the board of Universal Music Group NV, the world’s largest music company, citing obligations arising from his recent investments.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob

media:content.media:description: Bill Ackman Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

item.title: KDDI to Buy Back $2.7 Billion of Stock Including Kyocera’s Stake
item.description: KDDI Corp. said it will buy back as much as ¥400 billion ($2.7 billion) worth of its shares, with Toyota Motor Corp. and Kyocera Corp. tendering their stakes.
item.dc:creator: Mayumi Negishi

media:content.media:description: A KDDI Corp. logo.

item.title: Rakuten Reports Another Loss After Financing Costs Mount
item.description: Rakuten Group Inc. reported its 19th straight quarterly loss after financing costs mounted and it sought to turn around its struggling wireless operations.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga

media:content.media:description: Visitors in the AI zone at the Rakuten Optimism event in Tokyo, in 2024.

item.title: Atos Announces Reorganization Aiming to Restart Sales Growth
item.description: Atos SE said it will simplify its organization and cut expenses as the embattled French IT group works to return to growth after years of setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: The Atos SE headquarters in Paris. Photographer: Anita Pouchard Serra/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Baidu Plans Robotaxi Expansion to Europe and Turkey
item.description: Baidu Inc. is planning to test and eventually launch autonomous ride-hailing service Apollo Go in Europe and Turkey, joining a growing number of Chinese self-driving technology companies in embarking on a global expansion.
item.dc:creator: Linda Lew, Zheping Huang

media:content.media:description: A Baidu Inc. Apollo RT6 robotaxi in Wuhan, China. Source: /Bloomberg

item.title: Tencent, Alibaba Results Key to Cementing China Tech Stock Rally
item.description: Earnings from the two biggest names in China tech are the next big watchpoint for clues on whether one of 2025’s hottest stock rallies is back on track.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang, Bailey Lipschultz

item.title: Carlyle Seeks $1.2 Billion Loan for India Hexaware M&A Refinance
item.description: Carlyle Group Inc is seeking about $1.2 billion in a syndicated loan to refinance debt used to acquire Mumbai-based software firm Hexaware Technologies Ltd., according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Chien Mi Wong, Kari Soo Lindberg

media:content.media:description: Hexaware’s CEO, Srikrishna Ramakarthikeyan, second from left, and other executives attend the company’s listing ceremony at the National Stock Exchange in Mumbai in February.

item.title: Samsung to Buy FläktGroup for €1.5 Billion in Data Center Play
item.description: Samsung Electronics Co. has agreed to buy FläktGroup Holding GmbH for €1.5 billion ($1.7 billion), acquiring the European heating and cooling specialist in its biggest overseas takeover in eight years.
item.dc:creator: Yoolim Lee

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken on April 30, 2024, Samsung manufactured air-conditioning units are seen outside a building in Seoul. (Photo by ANTHONY WALLACE / AFP) (Photo by ANTHONY WALLACE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: SoftBank Profit Doubles After ByteDance, Didi Values Surge
item.description: SoftBank Group Corp.’s profit soared 124% after valuations of tech startups like ByteDance Ltd. rose, in a boost for the Japanese company’s aggressive data center investment plans.
item.dc:creator: Min Jeong Lee

media:content.media:description: A SoftBank Corp. store in Yamato, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan, on Thursday, May 1, 2025. SoftBank Group is scheduled to release earnings figures on May 13. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

item.title: Nubank Shares Dip Post-Earnings as Funding Weighs on Margins
item.description: Shares of Nu Holdings Ltd. fell after reporting first quarter results that showed strong revenue growth weighed down by higher spending to attract new clients and protect against potential bad loans.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cancel

media:content.media:description: Nubank headquarters in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Wednesday, May 15, 2024. Nu Holdings Ltd., one of the world's largest digital banks, surpassed 100 million clients across its operations in Brazil, Mexico and Colombia.

item.title: Trump’s Mideast Visit Opens Floodgate of AI Deals Led by Nvidia
item.description: The Trump administration is clearing a path for two key Persian Gulf allies to pursue their artificial intelligence ambitions — and some of the biggest US tech companies are seizing on that opening with plans to spend billions of dollars in the region.
item.dc:creator: Michael Shepard, Mackenzie Hawkins, Ian King

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks during the Saudi-US business investment forum in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on May 13, 2025.

item.title: Mobile Games Turn Into Boom-or-Bust Industry as Spending Rises
item.description: Mobile gamers ramped up their spending by 4% last year even as the number of downloads and new releases fell, highlighting the narrowing of the industry to a handful of huge titles that dominate users’ time.
item.dc:creator: Vlad Savov

media:content.media:description: A gamer plays in a Honor of Kings tournament in Yantai, East China's Shandong province, on May 27, 2023.

item.title: Nvidia CEO Compensation Jumps to $50 Million After Stock Surge
item.description: The pay package of Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang jumped 46% to nearly $50 million in fiscal 2025 after the company he co-founded became the top beneficiary of an artificial intelligence spending boom.
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, Nvidia’s co-founder and chief executive officer, saw his pay package climb to nearly $50 million in the last fiscal year.

item.title: Airbnb Revamps App With Luxury Services, Curated Tours in Push Beyond Stays
item.description: After more than a year of teasing expansion plans beyond home rentals, Airbnb Inc. launched an overhauled app that’s not just for homeowners and travelers, but also for personal chefs, hair stylists, trainers and tour operators to offer their services widely.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung

media:content.media:description: Airbnb is launching 10 new categories of services, personal chef bookings.

item.title: DeepSeek’s ‘Tech Madman’ Founder Is Threatening US Dominance in AI Race
item.description: The company’s sudden emergence illustrates how China’s industry is thriving despite Washington’s efforts to slow it down.

media:content.media:description: DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng meeting with President Xi Jinping in Beijing in February.

item.title: US Plans to Grant Saudi Arabia More Access to AI Chips | Bloomberg Technology
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss Nvidia’s plans to sell advanced semiconductors to Humain for a massive data center project in Saudi Arabia. Plus, City Index Senior Analyst Fiona Cincotta explains why markets aren’t out of the woods yet. All this as US President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman meet in Riyadh to announce new investments. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500, Nasdaq 100 Erase 2025 Drop as Trade Hope Sparks Rebound
item.description: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 indexes turned higher for the year on Tuesday, reversing multi-trillion dollar routs, as enthusiasm for US stocks grows with global trade tensions cooling after the Trump administration and China agreed to temporarily lower tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

item.title: Google Backs Saudi AI Fund as Trump, MBS Tout New Investments
item.description: Saudi Arabian venture capital firm STV launched a $100 million artificial intelligence fund with backing from Google as part of a package of deals announced during US President Donald Trump’s visit to the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Yassmin Jabri

item.title: Milei Scraps Tariffs That Put $2,000 Price Tags on iPhones
item.description: President Javier Milei cut tariffs that made Argentina one of the most expensive places in the world to buy iPhones after decades of protectionist policies, delivering on a campaign promise to open up the economy to trade.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie, Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Apple’s iPhone 16 costs more than $2,000 in Argentina.

item.title: US Warns That Using Huawei AI Chip ‘Anywhere’ Breaks Its Rules
item.description: The Commerce Department issued guidance stating that the use of Huawei Technologies Co.’s Ascend artificial intelligence chips “anywhere in the world” violates the government’s export controls, escalating US efforts to curb technological advances in China.
item.dc:creator: Lynn Doan

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. chip.

item.title: Microsoft Is Cutting Thousands of Employees Across the Company
item.description: Microsoft Corp. said it will cut 6,000 workers across the company in an effort to reduce management layers.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford, Matt Day

media:content.media:description: The Microsoft campus in Mountain View, California, US.

item.title: Trump to Rewrite AI Chip Curbs Reviled by Nvidia and US Allies
item.description: The Trump administration plans to overhaul regulations on the export of semiconductors used in artificial intelligence, tossing out a Biden-era approach that had drawn strenuous objections from US allies and companies including Nvidia Corp. and Oracle Corp.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Stephanie Lai

item.title: Top Asia Advisers at Morgan Stanley, UBS See China Revival
item.description: Two senior executives from Morgan Stanley and UBS Group AG who advise Asia’s ultra-wealthy are seeing renewed investor optimism over China following a weekend truce between the two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Cathy Chan, Denise Wee

media:content.media:description: Amy Lo

item.title: Restaurant Tech Startup Owner.com Hits $1 Billion Valuation
item.description: Meritech and Headline co-led a $120 million funding around for the startup.
item.dc:creator: Katie Roof

media:content.media:description: The San Francisco-based startup helps restaurants improve their visibility in online search.

item.title: US Mulls Letting UAE Buy Over a Million Leading Nvidia Chips
item.description: The Trump administration is weighing a deal that would allow the United Arab Emirates to import more than a million advanced Nvidia Corp. chips, people familiar with the matter said, a quantity that far exceeds limits under Biden-era AI chip regulations — and one that’s raised concerns that American hardware risks ending up in China’s hands.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard, Ben Bartenstein

media:content.media:description: A Nvidia chip. Photographer: AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Google Unveils Major Android Redesign Ahead of iPhone Overhaul
item.description: Google unveiled the biggest update to its Android mobile operating system in years, weeks before its biggest competitor in the space, Apple Inc., is expected to give a preview of its overhauled iPhone software.
item.dc:creator: Vlad Savov
